quotes.topic_title: Why storytelling matters in business communication
quotes.text: Because to be a storyteller means you have to separate yourself from the herd, and in their mind, that risks them getting picked off, right? Getting picked off by some predator. But the alternative is you're in the herd, which means you're forgettable.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A contrarian framing that positions standing out through story as less risky than blending in and being ignored.

quotes.topic_title: Why storytelling matters in business communication
quotes.text: Because that's what happens if we don't speak in story.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical reminder that story is the default mode for making messages stick in real-world communication settings.

quotes.topic_title: Why storytelling matters in business communication
quotes.text: Our minds are not designed to remember a pie chart or facts or statistics or platitudes or ideas that are not attached to imagery.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A mental model for business communication: attach ideas to imagery via narrative rather than relying on abstract information.

quotes.topic_title: Why storytelling matters in business communication
quotes.text: So the risk you take if you're not telling stories is that you will be forgotten. 100%. You will be forgotten.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable statement that reframes storytelling as essential for retention and impact, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get very tactical about how to tell better stories both in life and in work, how to feel more comfortable speaking on stage, how to come up with story ideas that you can deploy when the need arises.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets clear, practitioner-focused takeaways: tactical storytelling, stage comfort, and building a ready-to-use bank of story ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Why every good story is centered around one five-second moment of transformation and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable storytelling framework—the “five-second moment”—as the core of effective narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Matthew is a 59-time Moth Story Slam winner, and nine-time Grand Slam champ.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete credential that signals deep, repeated real-world validation of the guest’s storytelling approach.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical observation for SaaS builders: assume messy inputs and design import flows accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like error on line 53, and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a specific UX failure mode and its consequence—onboarding drop-off—useful for prioritizing better error handling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never-ending sink for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A cautionary observation about how “simple” CSV import features can quietly balloon into ongoing engineering and support cost.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Six months later, you're fixing yet another date, conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of the long tail of edge cases that makes data import deceptively expensive to maintain.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like error on line 53, and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights how poor error messaging in onboarding flows can directly prevent activation and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their operation produces the only stress-free 100% wild-harvested red meat on the market.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A specific, differentiating claim that illustrates how to position a product with a clear, memorable unique attribute.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Actively managing Maui's invasive access to your populations, helping to restore balance to vulnerable ecosystems, food systems, and communities in Hawaii.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: An example of mission-driven framing that ties a product to broader ecosystem and community outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Matthew’s approach: teaching meets storytelling
quotes.text: I tried to make my book as actionable as possible.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Highlights an explicit practitioner-first goal: optimize storytelling guidance for immediate application, not theory.

quotes.topic_title: Matthew’s approach: teaching meets storytelling
quotes.text: I think the only reason I'm successful in what I do is that I've been a teacher for 25 years and I'm a storyteller.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Offers a mental model for effective instruction: combine pedagogy (teaching) with craft (storytelling) to make methods stick.

quotes.topic_title: Matthew’s approach: teaching meets storytelling
quotes.text: So the two of those things come together pretty well for me.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Reinforces the methodology that practical storytelling instruction emerges from the intersection of teaching experience and storytelling practice.

quotes.topic_title: Matthew’s approach: teaching meets storytelling
quotes.text: all good stories are rooted in this five second moment of someone's life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete, counterintuitive storytelling framework: anchor narratives around a single pivotal micro-moment.

quotes.topic_title: The five-second moment: transformation or realization
quotes.text: every story is about a singular moment. I call it five seconds. It can be one second honestly. It's a moment of either transformation, meaning I'm telling you a story about how I once used to be one kind of person and now I'm a new kind of person. Or more common is realization. Which is I used to think something and then some stuff happened and now I think a new thing.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Defines a practical framework for building stories around a single “five-second moment” of transformation or realization.

quotes.topic_title: The five-second moment: transformation or realization
quotes.text: it's an accumulation of events and feelings and thoughts that ultimately result in a singular moment where that flip actually happens.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Gives a clear method for structuring narrative: stack context until it triggers one decisive “flip” moment.

quotes.topic_title: The five-second moment: transformation or realization
quotes.text: the purpose of a story is essentially to bring that moment to the greatest clarity possible to the audience. So that the audience can, in a way experience that flip that transformation or realization along with the storyteller.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Actionable storytelling goal: optimize everything in the story to help the audience feel the change moment firsthand.

quotes.topic_title: The five-second moment: transformation or realization
quotes.text: So 98% of the story is the context to bring that singular moment into fruition.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Counterintuitive ratio that reframes most of storytelling as context-building in service of one pivotal moment.

quotes.topic_title: The five-second moment: transformation or realization
quotes.text: all of the stories of the world that are worth hearing and truly just about every story told that qualifies as a story has one of those moments.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A strong, memorable claim that can be used as a diagnostic: if there’s no “moment,” it’s not a story yet.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Eileen in class and Star Wars
quotes.text: That was my five-second moment. That was the moment of realization where I understood that Eileen trusted me, felt confident enough in my classroom that she could be herself, that she could fire off a quip at a teacher, sort of take a shot at me.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Defines the “five-second moment” as a practical lens for identifying the precise instant a character (or relationship) changes.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Eileen in class and Star Wars
quotes.text: I could make that into a five or six minute story about my journey with this student.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Shows how a tiny moment of change can be expanded into a full narrative by building toward it with selected backstory and steps.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Eileen in class and Star Wars
quotes.text: And when the final moment comes for Luke Skywalker to defeat the Empire, his vision of using technology, a spaceship and a blaster to destroy the Empire, all of that goes away, and he turns off his technology in his spaceship. Instead, he uses The Force to guide his weapon to defeat the enemy.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A concrete pop-culture example of a “moment of change” where the protagonist shifts from one worldview (tech) to another (faith).

quotes.topic_title: Examples: Eileen in class and Star Wars
quotes.text: And that's why a story like that resonates with us in a way that another story might not, because we all understand what it's like to not believe in something and then find belief in something.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Explains a transferable mechanism for resonance: audiences connect to belief-change arcs because they mirror a universal human experience.

quotes.topic_title: Start at the end: opposites define story shape
quotes.text: So we start as storytellers at the end.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A simple methodology: begin by identifying the ending (the change) before designing the rest of the story.

quotes.topic_title: Start at the end: opposites define story shape
quotes.text: And then whatever that moment is, in my case, I discover that Eileen has more confidence than I realized and is ready to take a big step forward. What's the opposite of me realizing Eileen has confidence and is ready to step forward? It is, Eileen does not have confidence, and I need to help her find that confidence.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical “opposites” technique for deriving a story’s beginning from its ending transformation.

quotes.topic_title: Start at the end: opposites define story shape
quotes.text: Essentially, a story is about these two moments in time, a beginning and an end, and they're operating in opposition to each other.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for story shape: define the start and end as opposing states.

quotes.topic_title: Start at the end: opposites define story shape
quotes.text: Even knowing it doesn't mean the story's ruined. We can get there in a very entertaining way.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A counterintuitive point that predictability doesn’t kill engagement—the execution of the journey matters.

quotes.topic_title: Start at the end: opposites define story shape
quotes.text: But yeah, every story should be essentially a beginning and an end and opposition to each other, and you should start at the end, that guarantees that you have something important to say rather than what most people do, which is they simply report on their lives. They just tell you stuff that happened over the course of time in some chronological way that ultimately doesn't lead to anything.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for avoiding chronological “reporting” by anchoring the narrative to a meaningful end-state.

quotes.topic_title: Why change creates universal connection
quotes.text: You've never asked to see a PowerPoint presentation a second time. You've never gone to bed and dreamt about a PowerPoint presentation. You've never heard someone give a keynote and thought, I hope I get to watch that keynote again tomorrow. But movies, you'll watch a movie a hundred times, because it's a story, and our minds are wired to enjoy story over and over and over again.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A vivid, practitioner-relevant contrast that explains why story beats informational formats for retention and repeat engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Why change creates universal connection
quotes.text: Well, I think that actual moment of transformation lends importance to the story and allows the audience to connect to it.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A clear story-building principle: anchor narratives around a transformation moment to create meaning and connection.

quotes.topic_title: Why change creates universal connection
quotes.text: If I report it on my day to you, my day teaching in a classroom, I am unlikely to connect with you unless you are also a teacher and you experienced things similar to me.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to avoid “day report” storytelling because it limits audience relatability to shared context.

quotes.topic_title: Why change creates universal connection
quotes.text: But when we talk about change, change has a great universal appeal.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for broadening relevance: emphasize change to make stories resonate across different audiences.

quotes.topic_title: Why change creates universal connection
quotes.text: When we do change, when we're focused in on that change, we increase exponentially the universal appeal to the story and our ability to connect to an audience.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for storytellers: focusing on change dramatically expands how widely a story connects.

quotes.topic_title: The dinner test and telling your own story
quotes.text: So the dinner test is the idea that when you're telling a story in a formal way, if you're performing on a stage or delivering a keynote or even delivering a pitch to entrepreneurs or a sales pitch, essentially the story that you're telling should be very closely related to the story you would tell someone if you were having dinner.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Introduces the core “dinner test” framework for keeping formal storytelling grounded in natural, conversational delivery.

quotes.topic_title: The dinner test and telling your own story
quotes.text: So weird things that people do should not be done. Like opening a story with unattributed dialogue.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Actionable warning against common stage-storytelling gimmicks that feel unnatural to audiences.

quotes.topic_title: The dinner test and telling your own story
quotes.text: And I said, "Well, let me tell you Lenny. Bang, the door opened." You would not have dinner with me again.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A memorable example illustrating why “sound effect” openings are jarring in real conversation and should be avoided in talks.

quotes.topic_title: The dinner test and telling your own story
quotes.text: So if you're telling a story about someone else, essentially, you might as well be telling fiction.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Counterintuitive principle that stories not centered on the teller lose immediacy and emotional reality for the audience.

quotes.topic_title: The dinner test and telling your own story
quotes.text: But what I teach them to do is to tell stories about themselves. And then at some point in the story about themselves, they're going to talk about how the experience of their parent or grandparent during the Holocaust has informed or changed their own life too.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical method for making “someone else’s story” compelling by anchoring it in the storyteller’s own change and vulnerability.

quotes.topic_title: Why vacation stories fail and where to start
quotes.text: Most vacation stories are just simply a recounting of your vacation at the expense of another person. So unless something happened on that vacation where you experienced one of these five second fundamental moments of change, nobody cares about your vacation. And if something did happen, only be talking about the moment when it happened.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical filter for deciding whether a vacation story is worth telling and how to focus it on a single meaningful change moment.

quotes.topic_title: Why vacation stories fail and where to start
quotes.text: If your location is paramount to your story because you want people to know you were in Aruba, then you have to understand, no one actually cares that you were in Aruba and you're just a terrible person for trying to dump that on someone and use up their time so you can relive your vacation and perhaps humble brag about how much fun you had.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that “context” often serves the storyteller’s ego, not the audience’s interest.

quotes.topic_title: Why vacation stories fail and where to start
quotes.text: The shortest version of every story is the best version of every story. Starting as close to the end of a story is always the best place to begin.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A simple, actionable editing rule: compress and begin near the climax to maximize engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Why vacation stories fail and where to start
quotes.text: Kurt Vonnegut said, "Start as close to the end as possible."
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for where to start a story—skip setup and jump to the turning point.

quotes.topic_title: Why vacation stories fail and where to start
quotes.text: And it is, of all the things I help people with their stories, the most frequent suggestion that I make for revision is you've started your story in the wrong place.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A diagnostic for revising stories: the biggest fix is often moving the starting line closer to the payoff.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes: keeping audiences wondering what’s next
quotes.text: If your audience isn't wondering what you're about to say, they're no longer listening to you. And you have to internalize that in a deep and fundamental way.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Defines stakes as sustained audience curiosity and frames it as the core condition for attention.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes: keeping audiences wondering what’s next
quotes.text: I assume all the time, 100% of the time, that no one wants to hear anything I have to say. And so I am relentless in my attempt to get the audience to be constantly wondering what the next sentence is.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A contrarian mindset shift for presenters: earn attention continuously rather than assuming it.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes: keeping audiences wondering what’s next
quotes.text: I always say you should have, what I call an elephant at the beginning of the story, which is actually a big spaceship shooting at a little spaceship or a police officer chasing a guy across a roof. We have to immediately know that something is at stakes.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Introduces the “elephant” framework: open with an immediate, high-salience stake to hook the audience.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes: keeping audiences wondering what’s next
quotes.text: I call something called a backpack, which is, you tell the audience what your plan is before you carry out your plan so that they sort of have your hopes and dreams packed up with them as well.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical technique for increasing stakes by making the audience invested in the intended outcome before obstacles appear.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes: keeping audiences wondering what’s next
quotes.text: So inevitable means there has to be enough information placed earlier in the story so that when the surprise happens, the audience goes, "Yes." But also you have to be clever enough to plant that information in such a way that the audience doesn't see the surprise coming.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A clear methodology for crafting endings: seed the payoff early while disguising it to preserve surprise.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes in practice: Charity Thief and pacing
quotes.text: It needs a lot of stakes because two thirds of the story nothing really happens. Two thirds of the story is explaining how I end up on a porch. So that's not super entertaining unless I build in lots of stakes along the way.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical reminder to deliberately layer stakes when the plot is slow or mostly explanatory.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes in practice: Charity Thief and pacing
quotes.text: I'm not inventing anything, I'm just presenting the actual events in a way that makes you wonder what's going to happen next.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A clear methodology for increasing engagement without fabricating details: shape real events to create curiosity.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes in practice: Charity Thief and pacing
quotes.text: Some stories you don't have to worry so much about. I perform as a stripper in the break room of a McDonald's restaurant when I'm 19 years old for a bachelorette party. There are stakes in that story, but I don't need to put any of them in because everybody wants to know what's going to happen already.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A concrete example showing that inherently high-stakes premises can carry pacing without extra engineered tension.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes in practice: Charity Thief and pacing
quotes.text: I often say most communication in business is round white and flavorless intentionally so because a lot of people are afraid to stand out.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A contrarian diagnosis of why business communication is forgettable—and why storytelling requires differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Stakes in practice: Charity Thief and pacing
quotes.text: They love to think of themselves as storytellers, but when they come to me, they don't really want to be storytellers because to be a storyteller means you have to separate yourself from the herd, and in their mind that risks them getting picked off, getting picked off by some predator.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for the fear behind bland messaging: standing out feels like becoming a target.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: being remembered versus forgotten
quotes.text: Well, if you don't tell stories as part of your business, whether you're looking for investment, or speaking to your people, or speaking to customers, or clients, anything, if you're not telling stories, the good news is, you're just like everybody else. The bad news is, you're mediocre just like everybody else.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable framing of storytelling as the differentiator between standing out and being indistinguishable in business communication.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: being remembered versus forgotten
quotes.text: I often say most communication in business is round white and flavorless intentionally so because a lot of people are afraid to stand out.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A vivid mental model for why business messaging becomes bland—and how fear of standing out drives forgettable communication.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: being remembered versus forgotten
quotes.text: The first person came out with his childhood lunchbox, put it on a table, and told a story about how his parents had nothing while he was growing up. And yet they somehow kept him in new shoes, and a new backpack every year, and sent him to school with a lunch every day, and how much it meant to him, and how as an educator today he thinks about every single kid in his class like he was, a kid who had nothing except for all of his parents' hopes and dreams.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how vulnerability + imagery creates a lasting impression compared to abstract executive messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: being remembered versus forgotten
quotes.text: Our minds are not designed to remember a pie chart, or facts, or statistics, or platitudes, or ideas that are not attached to imagery.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A practical principle for practitioners: attach ideas to imagery via story if you want them remembered.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: being remembered versus forgotten
quotes.text: So the risk you take if you're not telling stories is that you will be forgotten, 100% you will be forgotten.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A high-stakes, quotable warning that clarifies the business impact of not using story in communication.

quotes.topic_title: Applying storytelling at work: Boris and Marsha
quotes.text: So he tells the story about his son, and he says, "Listen, there's nothing wrong with being sad, being upset with failure, but we cannot allow it to slow us down as much as we are right now. We have to think about my son. My son dragged his bat back to the dugout. He sat down, he sighed, his buddies patted him on the back, he collected himself, and he moved on. That's what we need to do. When we fail we're going to take a moment to collect ourselves, to think about the mistakes we made, to decide what we're going to do differently, and then we're going to move on."
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable coaching script for building sales resilience by translating a personal story into a behavioral standard.

quotes.topic_title: Applying storytelling at work: Boris and Marsha
quotes.text: It's much better than him standing up in front of his people and saying, "Listen, every time you guys fail to land a big sale, you wander around this office like you're dead, and you're wasting our time. It ends today. Today from now on when you fail, you're going to move on."
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Shows why story-based leadership can outperform direct admonishment when trying to change behavior at work.

quotes.topic_title: Applying storytelling at work: Boris and Marsha
quotes.text: So I compare it, I say, band-aids versus bricks. If you're building bricks, you're a storyteller that's capturing stories and building bricks, then you can eventually deploy into business. If you're a band-aid person, which is fine, that happens. "I have a problem, Matt, and I need a story to solve it."
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A memorable framework for using storytelling as a long-term capability (a story vault) rather than one-off problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: Applying storytelling at work: Boris and Marsha
quotes.text: Essentially what I'm doing there is I'm putting a band-aid over a problem, but you're not becoming a better storyteller. You're just using me as a consultant to help you generate a story that will solve a problem. That's fine, but you're going to need me the next time too. You're going to keep needing me because you're not really becoming a storyteller. Boris is building bricks. He is building a vault of stories that he can then deploy into his business.
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: Clarifies the operational difference between outsourcing story creation and building an internal repeatable storytelling system.

quotes.topic_title: Applying storytelling at work: Boris and Marsha
quotes.text: She said to me later, "I can't believe the difference that that 30 second anecdote meant to the narrative. Because suddenly when I reached the end of the narrative, people wanted to talk to me. People came up to me, and the first thing they said was," "Oh God, I remember I was feeling the same way during the pandemic."
quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.context: A specific example that a brief personal origin moment can dramatically increase audience connection and engagement in corporate storytelling.
